content:
Reptiles are ectothermic or poikilothermic creatures, which means that they depend on external sources to regulate their body temperature. They cannot produce their own body heat like endothermic mammals such as humans. Instead, they use heat from their surroundings to maintain their internal temperature. 

Reptiles have behavioral adaptations that enable them to regulate their body temperature. For instance, they bask in the sun and move to shady areas to cool down. Reptiles can also change their skin color to absorb or reflect heat as necessary. Additionally, some species burrow into the soil to escape harsh heat conditions or hide in water to regulate their temperature.

Body temperature regulation in reptiles influences their distribution and behavior. For example, cold-blooded reptiles such as turtles, snakes, and lizards are most active in the day, especially during the morning and evening when the temperature is warm. They will prefer habitats that provide basking areas such as rocks, logs, and open fields to warm their bodies. In contrast, reptiles that live in hot, arid environments may be active during the night when temperatures are cooler.

Overall, the ability of reptiles to regulate their body temperature enables them to occupy a wide range of habitats, from cold forests to hot deserts. It allows them to exploit environmental resources efficiently and influences their behavior and distribution.
